page.title: 04Devil's Den, Fyfield.
page.content: There is an old superstition that Devil's Den was an altar on which wild haired druids made offerings of human sacrifice. There are several local tales about the stones. The first tells of the { {devil}arriving at midnight driving eight white oxen. They try to pull down the stones, but in vain. Meanwhile a white rabbit sits watching high on the cross stone. Its eyes glow like fiery coals. Secondly, there is a belief that if water is poured into the hollows in the cross stone at night, a {demon} will come and drain away the water before morning. Some say that walking anticlockwise three times round the stone will make the devil appear before your closed eyes, and walking round five times results in a lady becoming pregnant.
